text:
ANDERSON COOPER: The
2013 CNN Hero of the Year
is Chad Pregracke.

CHAD PREGRACKE: Certainly,
I've winged a lot in my life.

But that night, I just was
not prepared to give a speech.
Umm.
AUDIENCE: [laughter]

CHAD PREGRACKE: Walking up
there, I felt bad to win,

just because everybody's
got great causes.
Everybody is just as passionate.
And again, the world wins.

I've met so many great people
today, the other heroes.

And I'm really moved
by all their stories

and all the things they
do around the world.

And I'm just going to give
10 grand to each of them,
because they're awesome.
So that's why I split the money.

And I gave 10,000 to
each different hero--
the other nine.

- Chad says his decision
to share his prize money

with the other top 10 CNN Heroes
was a spur of the moment call,

but he knew exactly what he
wanted to do with his portion.

CHAD PREGRACKE: A
little less known

thing that Living Lands and
Waters does is we grow trees.

A lot of people know
us for river cleanups.

My goal when I set out was to
get a million trees planted,

so I used the money to
help expand the nursery.
- (CHANTING) Plant a tree!

CHAD PREGRACKE: Since 2013, we
have planted our 1 millionth
tree, which is really cool.

- Planting trees,
removing trash,
keeping the planet cleaner.

Chad says that his
involvement with CNN Heroes

has helped him do
all of this and more.

CHAD PREGRACKE: So since
2013, a lot has happened.

By the end of this year, I'll
have done and helped facilitate
over 1,000 river cleanups.
Let's do this.

And have worked side by side
with over 100,000 volunteers.
Just make piles every 100 feet.

And removed over 10
million pounds of garbage.
All right.
It's really cool.

All you need to do is
just change your world,
whatever that is.
The river, for me, was my world.
It's a freezer.

It's like I didn't
like the problem.
Doing something about it.
All right.

Let's tie your bags up, and
we're going to head back.
- [cheering]
- Fantastic experience.

CHAD PREGRACKE:
Thanks a lot, man.

- Chad and his
group have invested

in state of the art
equipment that's taking
garbage removal to a new level.

CHAD PREGRACKE: We were able
to make such a big difference
in a quarter of the time.
So it's really rewarding really.

Just mountains of
garbage that would
have taken 30 times as long.

It's really the excavator, as
well, that's been helping us.

So our new goal is
a million pounds
a year for many years to come.
It's amazing.

It's like the excavator
with people power mixed--

it is a completely different
operation than it was in 2013.

- Chad Pregracke he has
spent much of his life

getting dirty in order
to keep the planet clean.

Today, he and his crew
have cleaned up 23 rivers
in 20 states.

CHAD PREGRACKE: What
is this thing, dude?

- We caught up
with Chad recently

on the Ohio River
near Cincinnati

where his operation
was in full swing
CHAD PREGRACKE: It's dusty.

So we've been on the Ohio
River for almost two months,

and we've done 241,000
pounds of garbage
in a 30, 40 mile stretch.

In the last 30 days, we pulled
out four boats, three cars,

over 255 gallon barrels,
thousands of tires,
millions of plastic bottles.

There are places--
the whole river
is just rafts of plastics.
It's bad.
It's really bad.
And let's see him up there.

- For Chad, the operation
is also a family affair.

CHAD PREGRACKE: What's really
cool is I live with my wife
on the barge and my daughter.
All right, folks.

My wife, Tammy, sets up
all of our big events.

Skylar's out here
now, my daughter.

She's really been
running the excavator,

and that's what she's
really getting good at.
SKYLAR PREGRACKE: Down?

- On top of the push
to clean up rivers,

Chad and company also
want to spread the word

and educate the public
about the harmful effects

that trash and waste
have on America's rivers.

- This is a lesson
on sustainability.
And what does sustain mean?

- Chad's group built
a floating classroom

so that teachers and
students can come on board
and learn first hand.
- When the vegetation's lost--

CHAD PREGRACKE: Garbage is
just one of the problems,

but the fact that all
these cities and towns

along the rivers-- they
all pull the drinking
water directly out of it.
17 bags.

And the stuff
we're pulling out--

I mean, barrels, and a decent
amount have substances in them

from oil to chemicals
to you name it.
A new front door, Tammy.

There is no other agency
or anything coming out here

to do this, so we're
pretty much the only people

with the scale of an operation
doing this like this.
And it needs to be done.
- It fertilizes the nutrients--

CHAD PREGRACKE: In conjunction
with all our cleanups,
adding education in there--
it's a necessity.

By the end of this year,
we'll have had over 10,000

either teachers or students
through the classroom.

That's how you not only get the
river clean, but keep it clean
is through education.

- But the amount of garbage
continues to pile up.

Just when Chad started to
wonder what to do with it all,

some sponsors stepped up to
help him with recycling efforts.

CHAD PREGRACKE: What's great
in the last three years

too is we built some
good partnerships.

They're taking our tires and
doing different recycling
things with it.

Pulling the stuff out of
the river is one thing,

but then disposing of it
properly is another thing.

And they're actually putting
them back in plastic parts

and shredding it
and recycling it.
- 10 bags.

- Chad says what he does is
not just about the environment,

it's an expression
of patriotism.
CHAD PREGRACKE: 12 bags.
Green is great.

I think what we're doing really
is more red, white, and blue.

I think it's really a
patriotic thing to do.

There's a lot of different
ways to serve your country.

I certainly feel like all these
volunteers have come out here--

my crew of people
that I work with

and all the other
great organizations
doing different things.

It's really-- that's
just being patriotic.

It's making the
country a better place.

We're going to clean
up some rivers today.
Are you guys ready?

- Decades of diligence and
determination have paid off.

For the results Chad sees
didn't happen all at once.

They were years and
years in the making.
CHAD PREGRACKE: Yeah!
Another fridge down.

It really does make
me pretty proud

that we are able to make
such a big difference.

I didn't start out
with a master plan.
I'm just an average person--
There we go.

--doing a unique job,
and it's had big results.

But I think if nothing else,
this is a perfect example

of an average
person who can make

a big difference with a lot
of help from a lot of people.

Good game, good game,
good game, good game.
Yes, we got it.
And it happens.
You can do it.
Yeah!
So do it.
